options.content:
**Fleet ID:** ${fleet_id}
**Instance Type:** ${instance_type} Related dashboards: Instances overview | EC2 fleet overview **Note:** This dashboard is only for EC2 fleets, for container fleets see the container performance dashboard Monitor each metric type for potential issues: - **Current Averages** shows overall instance health. When performance degrades, check CPU usage, memory consumption, and file system consumption for bottlenecks. - **Load Summary** tracks resource usage by game servers. High utilization patterns require checking induvidual session metrics and resource distribution like CPU and memory. - **Network** reflects instance connectivity. For latency or connectivity issues, investigate Network I/O, Packet rates, and Error counts. - **Disk** indicates disk performance. Slow response times suggest examining Disk operations, I/O wait times, and Pending operations. Click the information icon (â“˜) next to each graph for detailed analysis and troubleshooting steps.

panels.description:
#### What it means
Real-time gauges show overall processor utilization across all cores.

#### Why is it important?
It's critical for identifying immediate resource constraints that affect game server performance.
panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description:
#### What it means
Real-time gauges showing total RAM consumption percentage.

#### Why is it important?
It's critical for identifying immediate resource constraints affecting game server performance.
panels.title: Memory Usage

panels.description:
#### What it means
Real-time gauges showing root partition storage utilization.

#### Why is it important?
It's critical for identifying immediate resource constraints affecting game server performance.
panels.title: Filesystem Usage

panels.description: #### What it means Detailed breakdown of memory usage by type: - `used`: Actually used memory - `cached`: File system cache - `buffers`: System buffers #### Why is it important? - Shows memory pressure trends - Helps identify memory leaks - Reveals caching behavior #### How to identify the root cause - Investigate the game session graphs to figure out if the game server build is causing problems. - Check if it is across all instances or specific to this instance only. You can refer to the Instances overview dashboard. - Check if it is caused by a specific game session or all game sessions. #### How to mitigate the issue - Adjust the number of concurrent game servers running on the instance. - Adjust the instance type of the fleet. - Make changes to optimize game server code for memory.
panels.title: Memory Usage

panels.description: #### What it means It shows CPU time broken down by different usage types: - `user`: Time spent running user-space processes (game server application) - `system`: Time spent executing kernel-level operations - `wait`: Time spent waiting for I/O operations (disk, network) - `interrupt`: Time spent handling hardware interrupts - `softirq`: Time spent handling software interrupts (networking, scheduling) - `nice`: Time spent running user processes with modified priority - `steal`: Time that the CPU was requested but not received (virtual environments) #### Why is it important? - High `user` time suggests compute-intensive game logic - High `system` time indicates heavy kernel operations - High `wait` time shows I/O bottlenecks - High `interrupt`/`softirq` suggests network or hardware stress - High `steal` time indicates VM resource contention #### How to identify the root cause - Investigate the game session graphs to figure out if the game server build is causing problems. - Check if it is across all instances or this instance specifically. You can refer to the Instances overview dashboard. - Check if it is caused by a specific game session or all game sessions. #### How to mitigate the issue - Adjust the number of concurrent game servers running on the instance. - Adjust the instance type of the fleet. - Make changes to optimize game server code.
panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: #### What it means Comprehensive network performance metrics: - Bytes I/O: Data transfer volume - Transmit and receive data for each of the network interfaces on the instance #### Why is it important? - Monitors network health - Identifies connectivity issues - Helps diagnose latency problems #### How to identify the root cause - Investigate game session graphs to figure out if the game server build is causing problems. - Check whether it is across all instances or this instance only. You can refer to the Instances overview dashboard. - Check if it is caused by a specific game session or all game sessions. #### How to mitigate the issue - Adjust the number of concurrent game servers running on the instance. - Adjust the instance type of the fleet. - Make changes to optimize game server code.
panels.title: Network Bytes I/O

panels.description: #### What it means Disk performance metrics: - Operations I/O: Read/write operations per second - Bytes I/O: Data transfer volume - Operation Time: Time spent on disk operations - I/O Time: Total time disk is busy - Pending Operations: Queued disk operations #### Why is it important? - Identifies disk bottlenecks - Monitors storage performance - Helps optimize I/O patterns #### How to identify the root cause - Investigate game session graphs to figure out if the game server build is causing problems. - Check if it is across all instances or this instance only. You can refer to the Instances overview dashboard. - Check if it is caused by a specific game session or all game sessions. #### How to mitigate the issue - Adjust the number of concurrent game servers running on the instance. - Adjust the instance type of the fleet. - Make changes to optimize the game server code.
panels.title: Disk Operations I/O

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the number of game servers that crashed across the EC2 instance. #### Why is it important? A high number of game session crashes causes bad player experiences alongside resource waste and unwanted noise. #### How to mitigate the issue - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the EC2 Server Performance Overview dashboard for Game Server metrics.

targets.expr:
sum by(fleet_id) (game_server_crash{fleet_id="$fleet_id", host_id="$instance_id"})
or (vector(0) * on() group_left(fleet_id) (label_replace(vector(1), "fleet_id", "$fleet_id", "", "")))

panels.title: Game Server Crashes

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the game session IDs of the crashed game sessions. Click the link of game session ARN to navigate to the Server Performance dashboard. #### Why is it important? A high number of game session crashes can cause bad player experiences along with resource waste and unwanted noise. #### How to mitigate the issue - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the EC2 Server Performance Overview dashboard for Game Server metrics.
panels.title: Crashed Game Sessions
